name: phocoena-phocoena
definition: The harbour porpoise  is one of six species of porpoise.
description:
The Harbour porpoise is smaller than other porpoises and has a plump body and a dark gray to bluish back, pale belly with a rounded head.

The female of the species is usually slightly larger than the male.

The color of the animal varies from individual to individual, but the most common coloration pattern is a dark dorsal surface that shifts to a lighter colored hue ventrally.

When born, the young have a dull color and usually have birth lines that look like folds in their skin, which last for a few hours after birth.

Found in both salt and fresh water areas, harbour porpoise require a shallow coastal body of water.

They live in coastal regions in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and the Arctic Oceans, as well as the Black Sea and the Mediterranean regions.

They inhabit estuaries, bays, and river mouths, and sometimes go further upriver.

They prefer shallow, cold coastal waters.

The Harbour porpoise eats mainly smooth, non-spiny fish, such as herring, pollack, hake, cod and sardines.

Other sea creatures including cephalopods and shrimp are also eaten.

Significant predators of harbour porpoises include white sharks and killer whales.

Studies revealed that the local bottlenose dolphins attack and kill harbour porpoises without eating them due to competition for a decreasing food supply.

Grey seals are also known to attack harbour porpoises by biting off chunks of fat as a high energy source.

Harbour porpoises are polygynandrous, two or more males mating with two or more female porpoises.

Females give birth to a single calf every year or every second year, following a gestation of 10 to 11 months.

The mothers usually take their newborns to secluded coves for nursing.

Lactation lasts approximately 8 to 12 months, though calves start to eat solid food at around 5 months of age.

Young porpoises stay with their mothers after weaning for up to a further 9 months.

They reach sexual maturity at the age of 3 to 4 years.

The Harbour porpoise is a social species that travels in groups of two to five members, but larger groups can form during migration.

Some populations migrate, but on return to their usual areas they are territorial, and patrol certain areas.

These porpoises usually swim near the water's surface, rising up to the surface about every 25 seconds to breathe, and their blow is not easy to see at sea.

They do not present an especially playful attitude, taking no notice of boats and hardly ever leaping above the water.

They can often be detected by their loud puffing sound as they breathe at the surface.

According to IUCN's Red List, the global number for this species is no fewer than 700,000 individuals.

Harbour porpoises are classified currently as least concern on the list of threatened species.

related.definition: The blue whale  is a marine mammal belonging to the baleen whale parvorder, Mysticeti.
The killer whale or orca  is a toothed whale belonging to the oceanic dolphin family, of which it is the largest member.
The common minke whale is a species of minke whale within the suborder of baleen whales.
The short-finned pilot whale is one of the two species of cetaceans in the genus Globicephala, which it shares with the long-finned pilot whale.
The beluga whale   is an Arctic and sub-Arctic cetacean.
The striped dolphin  is an extensively studied dolphin found in temperate and tropical waters of all the world's oceans.
The narwhal is a medium-sized toothed whale that possesses a large tusk from a protruding canine tooth.
